Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: Collaborative Research: Broadband Wireless Access & Applications Center (BWAC)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed center seeks to establish a new Industry/University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) addressing broadband wireless access and applications. The center will focus on four areas: 1) enabling sharing up to many GHz of spectrum using technological advances and enabling platforms such as spectrum trading and auctions, and millimeter wave communications; 2) co-existence of heterogeneous devices (e.g. radar and communication systems); 3) providing connectivity for new applications such as wireless devices in the hospitals of the future, bringing wireless into the hospital in novel ways; and (d) improving electronic warfare technologies that address national-security issues.

The new center addresses an area of critical economic and has the potential to support development of broadband wireless as a platform for innovation as addressed in the White House PCAST Report. The proposed center has the potential to link a diverse set of member companies across the broadband industry sector with university discovery in this area. Moreover, the center participants have a history of start-up initiation, and the opportunity from new starts to leverage the ecosystem created by the center is significant. The center plans to impact students via their conduct of center research, curriculum development and REU site development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of wireless communications is evolving from third generation (3G) systems to the future fifth generation (5G) that are promising to offer unprecedented data rates at very low delay and new multimedia capabilities within a few years. With the recent advances, the wireless industry is beginning to contemplate new applications that exploit this massive increase in bandwidth, while simultaneously considering the implications of the data onslaught of emerging broadband connections that will someday offer data rates on the order of gigabits per second. These broadband speeds open the door for completely new mobile applications such as high definition video, networking cable replacements, and fully wireless hospital rooms of the future. Achieving these vastly broadband speeds requires a new vision and research direction, so that emerging research fields may be focused on these unprecedented “big data" capabilities that will be enabled with future wireless technologies. Bringing important emerging fields of wireless research, such as dynamic spectrum access with spectrum exchanges, coexistence of heterogeneous devices, wireless cyber security, millimeter wave antennas, propagation and communications, and low power ICs, is critical for assuring that the U.S. remains competitive in the coming decade of wireless evolution.

Intellectual Merit: To create a research capability that addresses the needs of industry while supporting academic research, the I/UCRC Broadband Wireless Access & Applications Center (BWAC) was established in 2013. The University of Arizona serves as the lead site for BWAC, while Auburn University is one of the collaborating sites. The partner universities and the industrial advisory board sought to address the needs of the new decade in wireless access and applications. The Auburn University Site brought in complementary expertise to the other BWAC sites, and closely worked with the other BWAC sites on the following tasks: (a) Enabling sharing up to many GHz of spectrum using technological advances and enabling platforms such as spectrum trading and auctions, and millimeter wave communications; (b) Co-existence of heterogeneous devices (e.g., LTE and WiFi); (c) Providing connectivity for new applications such as wireless devices in the hospitals of the future, and bringing wireless into the hospital in novel ways; and (d) Improving electronic warfare technologies that address national-security issues.

Broader Impact: This collaboration of academia and industry has been very helpful to develop the technologies and tools required for broadband access and applications of the future. The results of this collaboration had a direct effect on the public well-being with applications such as connectivity of medical devices and high-speed rural broadband access in new spectrum bands. Interactions with the BWAC members have exposed their needs and their sensitivity to sharing IP with universities. BWAC provided valuable opportunities to the Auburn faculty and graduate students to interact with industrial people, and to get a first-hand experience on working on industrial sponsored projects. Such experience has been very useful for their collaboration with the industry. The Auburn site has been committed to broadening participation to the center’s activities, which has been achieved through NSF REU and RET programs, participation of under-represented minority students and faculty in research projects, and through the involvement of multi-disciplinary projects.
